issues.description: The template's helper method singFarmSongVerse is declared without the Animal parameter (the parameter is commented out), while the problem UML and the solution both define singFarmSongVerse(animal: Animal): void. This mismatch is structural: students following the UML or the solution will expect to call singFarmSongVerse(animal) or implement it to accept an Animal, but the template's current signature prevents that and will cause confusion or compilation errors when they try to use the method as intended.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template method signature to accept an Animal parameter, matching the UML and solution: private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) { ... }. Also update the method body to use the passed animal (e.g., animal.getClass().getSimpleName() and animal.messageOnFeed()) so singFarmSong() can call singFarmSongVerse(animal) for each animal.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement displays the Animal constructor with a '-' (private) visibility marker ('- Animal(String): void'), which suggests a private constructor. If interpreted literally, that would prevent subclasses (Seal, Pig, Goat) from calling super(name). The textual instructions and the solution expect a publicly accessible constructor (solution uses public Animal(String)). This inconsistency between the UML visibility and the intended/implemented visibility can confuse students about the correct constructor visibility.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the UML or textual description so the Animal constructor is shown as public (use '+' in the UML: '+ Animal(String)') or explicitly state in the text that the constructor should be public (or protected) so subclasses can call super(name). This aligns the diagram with the intended implementation in the solution.
